articles.headline: Fed Is Poised to Aid Economy, but Impact Is Cloudy
articles.snippet: Some economists doubt the Federal Reserve’s expected resumption of buying Treasuries will have a big effect.
articles.abstract: Some economists doubt the Federal Reserve’s expected resumption of buying Treasuries will have a big effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is all but certain to move to spur the nation’s sputtering recovery this Wednesday, but most economists say it is unlikely to have a big impact on employment and growth.

articles.headline: Battle for Congress Comes to an End
articles.snippet: Beyond the results of the more than 500 House, Senate and governor’s races, the nation will be looking at the returns for answers to bigger questions.
articles.abstract: Beyond the results of the more than 500 House, Senate and governor’s races, the nation will be looking at the returns for answers to bigger questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even for a nation that is, by now, used to drinking in political news through a fire hose, election night on Tuesday could be a difficult one to absorb.

articles.headline: Winners Tuesday May Benefit From Economic Cycle
articles.snippet: The careers of politicians, especially governors who get elected during hard times and then preside over an upswing, benefit from economic recovery.
articles.abstract: The careers of politicians, especially governors who get elected during hard times and then preside over an upswing, benefit from economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The impact of the anti-incumbency wave of 2010  if, in fact, it materializes in the way polls would indicate  will be judged in the next few days by the number of seats that change hands in Washington and in statehouses across the country.

articles.headline: Financial Leaders Expect Shift of Power After Elections
articles.snippet: The expected prospect of a Republican takeover of the House, and possibly the Senate, would be welcomed by the banks, who want a break from the regulatory push.
articles.abstract: The expected prospect of a Republican takeover of the House, and possibly the Senate, would be welcomed by the banks, who want a break from the regulatory push.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most powerful executives in the banking industry didn’t go to the government.

articles.headline: Gene Patent Ruling Raises Questions for Industry
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s new stance that genes should not be eligible for patents is causing consternation in the biotechnology industry.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s new stance that genes should not be eligible for patents is causing consternation in the biotechnology industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Justice Department declared in a court filing late Friday that genes should not be eligible for patents because they are products of nature, Harold C. Wegner, an influential patent lawyer in Washington, did not mince words.

articles.headline: A Gold Mine in Attack Ads on Local TV
articles.snippet: Many stations that had severe advertising losses in 2009 are benefiting financially from the mudslinging ads in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Many stations that had severe advertising losses in 2009 are benefiting financially from the mudslinging ads in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Waco, Tex., $350 will usually buy 30 seconds of advertising time on a local evening newscast. But not this week.

articles.headline: G.M. Said to Plan Cut in U.S. Stake by a Third
articles.snippet: The government’s stake will reportedly be trimmed to less than 50 percent in a $10.6 billion initial public offering.
articles.abstract: The government’s stake will reportedly be trimmed to less than 50 percent in a $10.6 billion initial public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors will succeed in shrinking the federal government’s ownership stake to less than 50 percent in a $10.6 billion initial public offering later this month, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: G.O.P. Captures House, but Not Senate
articles.snippet: Republicans rode a tide of voter discontent to take control of the House of Representatives and expand their voice in the Senate in elections Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Republicans rode a tide of voter discontent to take control of the House of Representatives and expand their voice in the Senate in elections Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and expanded their voice in the Senate, riding a wave of voter discontent as they dealt a setback to President Obama just two years after his triumphal victory.

articles.headline: Japan’s Auto Parts Makers Try to Anticipate Shift to Electric Cars
articles.snippet: Spurred by fears of the eventual demise of gasoline engines, car manufacturers and parts makers are joining forces to prepare for the future.
articles.abstract: Spurred by fears of the eventual demise of gasoline engines, car manufacturers and parts makers are joining forces to prepare for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMAMATSU, Japan  People here refer to it as “electric vehicle shock.”
